title: Napoleon and the Jews
description: In 1799, during Napoleon Bonaparte's campaign in the Middle East, he issued a proclamation offering Palestine as a homeland for the Jewish people. This was one of the earliest instances of a prominent leader endorsing the idea of a Jewish state in Palestine.

title: The Term 'Zionism'
description: The term 'Zionism' was first coined in 1882 by Nathan Birnbaum, an Austrian-Jewish writer and political activist. Zionism came to define the national movement for the return of the Jewish people to their homeland and the resumption of Jewish sovereignty in Israel.

title: Theodor Herzl Publishes 'Der Judenstaat'
description: In 1896, Theodor Herzl, an Austro-Hungarian journalist, published 'Der Judenstaat' (The Jewish State), a pamphlet arguing for the establishment of a Jewish state as a solution to anti-Semitism in Europe.

title: First Zionist Congress is Held in Switzerland
description: The First Zionist Congress was held in Basel, Switzerland, in 1897. It was organized by Theodor Herzl and marked the formal establishment of the World Zionist Organization, which aimed to create a Jewish homeland in Palestine.

title: Chaim Weizmann Visits Palestine
description: Chaim Weizmann, a prominent Zionist leader who would later become the first President of Israel, visited Palestine for the first time in 1907. His visit was crucial in laying the groundwork for future Jewish settlement and political efforts in the region.

title: Najib Nassar Publishes Al-Karmel Newspaper
description: In 1908, Palestinian writer Najib Nassar began publishing Al-Karmel, a newspaper that strongly opposed Zionist colonization in Palestine. It became a significant platform for Palestinian nationalist thought.

title: Sykes-Picot Agreement Signed
description: The Sykes-Picot Agreement, a secret deal signed in 1916 by Britain and France, divided the Ottoman Empire's Arab provinces outside the Arabian Peninsula into spheres of influence. This agreement laid the groundwork for modern political boundaries in the Middle East.

title: Herbert Samuel's Secret Memorandum
description: In 1916, Herbert Samuel, a British Cabinet member and a Zionist, wrote a secret memorandum titled 'The Future of Palestine.' He advocated for British support of Zionist settlement in Palestine, influencing British policy towards the region.

title: Balfour Declaration Created
description: The Balfour Declaration, issued by the British government in 1917, promised support for the establishment of a 'national home for the Jewish people' in Palestine. This declaration was a pivotal moment in the history of Zionism.

title: King-Crane Commission Conducted
description: In 1919, the King-Crane Commission was conducted by the United States to assess the disposition of non-Turkish areas within the former Ottoman Empire, including Palestine. The commission's findings were critical of Zionist aspirations, favoring Arab independence.

title: League of Nations Approves British Mandate for Palestine
description: The League of Nations formally approved the British Mandate for Palestine in 1922, which included the objective of establishing a Jewish national home. This mandate legally recognized British administration in the region.

title: Al-Buraq Uprising
description: The Al-Buraq Uprising in 1929 was a significant Palestinian revolt against increased Jewish immigration and land purchases. It was named after the Western Wall, known in Arabic as Al-Buraq, and marked the first large-scale anti-Zionist riots.

title: Mass Protests Against Jewish Immigration
description: In 1933, mass protests erupted in Palestine against the increasing Jewish immigration. These demonstrations reflected the growing tensions between Jewish settlers and the Arab population.

title: Izz ad-Din al-Qassam Killed by British Forces
description: Izz ad-Din al-Qassam, a Palestinian militant leader, was killed by British forces in 1935. His death inspired further resistance and he became a symbol of Palestinian nationalism.

title: Six-Month Long General Strike
description: In 1936, Palestinians launched a six-month general strike to protest Jewish immigration and British colonial rule. This strike marked the beginning of the Arab Revolt, a major uprising against British and Zionist presence in Palestine.

title: Peel Commission Recommends Partition
description: The Peel Commission, in 1937, recommended the partition of Palestine into separate Jewish and Arab states, with population transfers to ensure each state's homogeneity. This was the first official proposal for partition.

title: Ahmed Yassine
description: the birth of Ahmed Yassine who was later assassinated in 2004, in Gaza, was the founder and political/spiritual leader of Hamas. Paralyzed since a sports accident at age 12, he was also visually impaired. An opponent of the Oslo Accords and any negotiated solution with Israel, Yassine firmly refused to recognize the State of Israel and commanded many attacks on israeli military.

title: Britain Smashes the Arab Revolt
description: By 1938, British forces had suppressed the three-year-long Arab Revolt. The rebellion had aimed to end British rule and halt Jewish immigration, but its defeat led to increased British and Zionist control in Palestine.

title: Armed Zionist Group Irgun Launches Attacks
description: In 1939, the armed Zionist group Irgun began a series of violent attacks against Palestinian targets. Irgun, also known as Etzel, was a paramilitary organization that sought to advance Jewish statehood in Palestine through militant means.

title: Biltmore Conference in New York City
description: The Biltmore Conference, held at the Biltmore Hotel in New York City in 1942, was a pivotal Zionist meeting where leaders, including David Ben-Gurion, called for the establishment of a Jewish state in Palestine. This conference solidified U.S. Zionist support and marked a significant shift in Zionist strategy.

title: Irgun Bombs King David Hotel
description: On July 22, 1946, Irgun bombed the King David Hotel in Jerusalem, which was the British administrative headquarters. The attack killed 91 people and was one of the most infamous acts of violence in the British Mandate of Palestine, escalating tensions in the region.

title: UN Adopts Partition Plan for Palestine
description: In November 1947, the United Nations adopted Resolution 181, proposing a partition plan for Palestine, which aimed to create separate Jewish and Arab states. The plan was accepted by the Jewish community but rejected by the Palestinians, leading to increased tensions and conflict.

title: Haganah Bombs Semiramis Hotel
description: In January 1948, the armed Zionist group, Haganah, bombed the Semiramis Hotel in Jerusalem. This attack resulted in the death of more than 20 people, contributing to the escalating violence in the region.

title: Zionist Forces Attack Qisarya
description: In February 1948, Zionist forces attacked the village of Qisarya near Haifa. This assault is considered an early example of ethnic cleansing, as it aimed to clear the area of its Palestinian inhabitants.

title: Massacre at Deir Yassin
description: In April 1948, members of the Stern Gang and Irgun forces carried out a massacre in the Palestinian village of Deir Yassin, near Jerusalem. This event led to the death of many villagers and heightened the fear and hostility between Jewish and Palestinian communities.

title: Creation of the State of Israel
description: In May 1948, the State of Israel was officially established, sparking a regional conflict. The United States and the Soviet Union immediately recognized the new state, while neighboring Arab countries rejected its creation and moved to intervene militarily.

title: Assassination of Folke Bernadotte
description: In September 1948, the Stern Gang assassinated Folke Bernadotte, a Swedish diplomat and the United Nations-appointed mediator in Palestine. His assassination was a significant blow to diplomatic efforts to resolve the ongoing conflict.

title: UN General Assembly Passes Resolution 194
description: In December 1948, the UN General Assembly passed Resolution 194, affirming the right of Palestinian refugees to return to their homes. This resolution has remained a central point of contention in the Israeli-Palestinian conflict.

title: Armistice Agreements Signed
description: In February 1949, armistice agreements were signed between Israel and its neighboring Arab countries: Lebanon, Syria, Jordan, and Egypt. These agreements formally ended the hostilities of the 1948 Arab-Israeli War but did not resolve the underlying conflict.

title: UN Establishes UNRWA
description: In December 1949, the United Nations established the United Nations Relief and Works Agency (UNRWA) to provide assistance to Palestinian refugees displaced by the 1948 conflict. UNRWA continues to operate, offering education, health care, and social services to millions of Palestinian refugees.

title: Jordan Assumes Control of the West Bank
description: In 1950, Jordan formally annexed the West Bank, including East Jerusalem, which it had captured during the 1948 Arab-Israeli War. This annexation was recognized only by the United Kingdom and Pakistan.

title: Israeli Massacres in Palestinian Villages
description: In 1956, Israeli forces carried out massacres in several Palestinian villages, including Qalqilya, Kufr Qassem, and Khan Younis. These attacks resulted in significant loss of life and heightened tensions in the region.

title: Formation of the Palestinian Liberation Organisation
description: In 1964, the Palestinian Liberation Organisation (PLO) was founded in Cairo with the goal of liberating Palestine through armed struggle and representing the Palestinian people on the international stage.

title: Israeli Massacre in As-Samu'
description: In 1966, Israeli forces attacked the West Bank village of As-Samu', killing many villagers and destroying numerous homes. This operation was a response to Palestinian guerilla activity and escalated Israeli-Palestinian hostilities.

title: Israel Occupies Additional Territories
description: During the Six-Day War in 1967, Israel occupied the Gaza Strip, the West Bank, East Jerusalem, the Golan Heights, and the Sinai Peninsula. This expanded Israeli control over historic Palestine and surrounding regions.

title: UN Security Council Resolution 242
description: In 1967, the UN Security Council passed Resolution 242, calling for the withdrawal of Israeli forces from territories occupied in the Six-Day War and the recognition of every state in the area's right to live in peace.

title: Israel Attacks Palestinian Fighters During Black September in Jordan
description: In 1970, during the Black September conflict, Israel conducted airstrikes against Palestinian fighters in Jordan. This conflict arose from clashes between the Jordanian army and the Palestine Liberation Organization (PLO), leading to significant casualties.

title: Arab League Recognizes PLO in Rabat, Morocco
description: In 1974, the Arab League officially recognized the Palestine Liberation Organization (PLO) as the sole legitimate representative of the Palestinian people. This recognition marked a significant step in the PLO's international standing.

title: Camp David Accords
description: In 1978, Egypt and Israel signed the Camp David Accords, brokered by U.S. President Jimmy Carter. This agreement led to a peace treaty between the two countries and Israel's withdrawal from the Sinai Peninsula.

title: Israel Invades Lebanon
description: In 1982, Israel launched a full-scale invasion of Lebanon to expel the Palestine Liberation Organization (PLO) and establish a security zone in southern Lebanon. This invasion led to a prolonged conflict and significant casualties.

title: First Intifada
description: In 1987, the First Intifada, a Palestinian uprising against Israeli occupation, began in the West Bank and Gaza Strip. The Intifada included widespread protests, civil disobedience, and violent clashes, significantly impacting the Israeli-Palestinian conflict.

title: Madrid Peace Conference
description: In 1991, the Madrid Peace Conference was held, bringing together Israeli, Palestinian, and Arab representatives to discuss peace in the Middle East. Despite high hopes, the conference ended without a breakthrough.

title: UN Security Council Resolution 338
description: Following the October War in 1973, the UN Security Council passed Resolution 338, calling for an immediate ceasefire and the implementation of Resolution 242, which demanded Israeli withdrawal from territories occupied in 1967.

title: Land Day
description: In 1976, Israel confiscated thousands of hectares of land from Palestinian citizens, prompting mass protests. These protests were brutally suppressed, resulting in deaths and injuries. Land Day is now commemorated annually to remember this event.

title: UN International Day of Solidarity with the Palestinian People
description: In 1977, the United Nations General Assembly established the International Day of Solidarity with the Palestinian People, observed annually on November 29. This day marks the anniversary of the UN's partition plan for Palestine in 1947.

title: The birth of Hamas
description: HAMAS formed in late 1987 at the beginning of the first Palestinian intifada (uprising). Its roots are in the Palestinian branch of the Muslim Brotherhood, and it is supported by a robust sociopolitical structure inside the Palestinian territories.

title: PLO Accepts UN Resolutions 242 and 338
description: In 1988, the PLO officially accepted UN Resolutions 242 and 338, recognizing the State of Israel and committing to a peaceful resolution of the conflict. This acceptance marked a significant shift in the PLO's strategy.

title: Multilateral Talks
description: Throughout the 1990s, numerous multilateral talks took place between Israel and Palestinian representatives. Despite these efforts, Palestinians remained no closer to achieving statehood.

title: Oslo Accords
description: The secret negotiations between the PLO and Israel that concluded in 1993 with the Oslo Accords marked a new chapter in Palestinian history. For some, these accords raised hopes for peace; for others, they dashed them entirely.

title: Oslo I Accord
description: In 1993, the PLO and Israel signed the Declaration of Principles on Interim Self-Government Arrangements, known as the Oslo I Accord. This agreement aimed to establish a framework for Palestinian self-governance in parts of the West Bank and Gaza Strip.

title: Oslo II Accord
description: In 1995, the PLO and Israel signed an interim agreement, known as the Oslo II Accord, granting the Palestinians some autonomy in certain parts of the West Bank and Gaza Strip.

title: Hebron Protocol
description: In 1997, the PLO and Israel signed an agreement requiring Israeli forces to partially withdraw from Hebron. This accord was part of ongoing efforts to implement the Oslo Accords.

title: Camp David II Summit
description: In 2000, the PLO and Israel renewed final status negotiations at the Camp David II Summit. Despite intense negotiations, the summit ended without an agreement, leading to increased tensions.

title: Yasser Arafat Dies
description: In 2004, Yasser Arafat, the long-time leader of the PLO and a central figure in the Palestinian national movement, died. His death marked the end of an era in Palestinian politics.

title: Israel-Hezbollah War
description: In 2006, war broke out between Israel and Hezbollah in Lebanon. This conflict, also known as the July War, resulted in significant destruction and loss of life on both sides.

title: Operation Cast Lead
description: In late 2008, Israel launched a major military operation, known as Operation Cast Lead, against the Gaza Strip. This operation resulted in high casualties and widespread destruction in Gaza.

title: Operation Protective Edge
description: In 2014, Israel launched Operation Protective Edge, the largest assault on Gaza since 1967. This operation resulted in significant casualties and damage, further escalating the Israeli-Palestinian conflict.

title: Israel Reoccupies West Bank Cities
description: In the wake of the Second Intifada, Israel reoccupied several Palestinian cities in the West Bank in 2002. This military operation aimed to curb Palestinian militant activities but resulted in significant hardships for civilians.

title: Israel's Disengagement from Gaza
description: In 2005, Israel unilaterally disengaged from the Gaza Strip, evacuating all Israeli settlers and military forces. This move was intended to reduce friction, but the region remained a flashpoint for conflict.

title: Peace Activists Break Israeli Blockade
description: In 2008, peace activists on two boats successfully broke the Israeli blockade of Gaza, delivering humanitarian aid and drawing international attention to the situation in the Gaza Strip.

title: Operation Pillar of Defense
description: In 2012, Israel launched Operation Pillar of Defense against the Gaza Strip, targeting Hamas militants and infrastructure. The operation resulted in significant casualties and heightened tensions in the region.

title: Israeli Elections: Likud Victory
description: In 2015, Israel held early elections for the 20th Knesset. The Likud party, led by Benjamin Netanyahu, won the elections, continuing its leadership and shaping Israeli policy.

title: UNESCO Resolution on Jerusalem
description: In October 2016, UNESCO adopted a resolution condemning Israeli actions in Jerusalem and the occupied territories, particularly regarding holy sites. The resolution sparked international controversy and highlighted tensions over Jerusalem's status.

title: Trump Recognizes Jerusalem as Israel's Capital
description: In December 2017, U.S. President Donald Trump recognized Jerusalem as Israel's capital, breaking with decades of international consensus and sparking protests across the Middle East and condemnation from the international community.

title: US Embassy Moved to Jerusalem
description: In May 2018, the United States officially moved its embassy from Tel Aviv to Jerusalem, coinciding with the 70th anniversary of Israeli independence and the Nakba. The move was met with massive Palestinian protests in Gaza, resulting in dozens of deaths.

title: Trump's 'Deal of the Century'
description: In January 2020, the Trump administration unveiled its Middle East peace plan, dubbed the 'Deal of the Century.' The plan heavily favored Israel, allowing it to annex settlements and maintain security control over the West Bank, while offering Palestinians limited autonomy. The plan was rejected by Palestinian leadership.

title: Abraham Accords Signed
description: In 2020, Israel signed normalization agreements with the United Arab Emirates and Bahrain, known as the Abraham Accords. These agreements marked a significant shift in Arab-Israeli relations, though Palestinians condemned them as a betrayal of their cause.

title: ICC Opens War Crimes Investigation
description: In March 2021, the International Criminal Court (ICC) opened a formal investigation into alleged war crimes committed in the Palestinian territories. The decision was condemned by Israel and the United States but welcomed by Palestinians and human rights groups.

title: May 2021 Gaza Conflict
description: In May 2021, a major escalation occurred between Israel and Hamas, triggered by tensions in Sheikh Jarrah and clashes at Al-Aqsa Mosque. The 11-day conflict resulted in over 250 Palestinian deaths in Gaza and significant destruction.

title: Shireen Abu Akleh Killed
description: In May 2022, renowned Palestinian-American Al Jazeera journalist Shireen Abu Akleh was shot and killed by Israeli forces while covering a raid in Jenin, West Bank. Her death sparked international outcry and investigations confirmed she was deliberately targeted despite wearing a press vest.

title: Most Right-Wing Israeli Government Formed
description: In December 2022, Benjamin Netanyahu formed Israel's most right-wing government in history, including far-right parties that openly advocate for settlement expansion and annexation of the West Bank. The coalition sparked concerns about Palestinian rights and the peace process.

title: Judicial Overhaul Protests in Israel
description: Throughout 2023, massive protests erupted in Israel against the government's proposed judicial reforms, which critics said would undermine democracy and concentrate power. The internal crisis divided Israeli society and occupied much of the government's attention.

title: Hamas Operation Al-Aqsa Flood
description: On October 7, 2023, Hamas launched a major military operation from Gaza into southern Israel, breaking through the barrier and engaging in combat with Israeli forces. The operation resulted in Israeli military and civilian casualties and the capture of hostages.

title: Israel Declares War on Gaza
description: Following the October 7 attack, Israel declared war on Gaza and launched a massive military campaign. A complete siege was imposed, cutting off food, water, electricity, and fuel. The campaign has resulted in unprecedented destruction and loss of life.

title: Temporary Ceasefire and Hostage Exchange
description: In November 2023, a temporary ceasefire was brokered to allow for the exchange of hostages held by Hamas and Palestinian prisoners held by Israel. The ceasefire lasted seven days before hostilities resumed.

title: South Africa Files Genocide Case at ICJ
description: In December 2023, South Africa filed a case at the International Court of Justice (ICJ) accusing Israel of committing genocide in Gaza. The case cited systematic destruction, mass killings, and statements by Israeli officials calling for the elimination of Gaza.

title: ICJ Orders Israel to Prevent Genocide
description: In January 2024, the International Court of Justice issued provisional measures ordering Israel to take immediate action to prevent genocidal acts in Gaza, ensure humanitarian aid access, and preserve evidence. The ruling was legally binding under international law.

title: ICC Prosecutor Seeks Arrest Warrants
description: In May 2024, the International Criminal Court prosecutor announced plans to seek arrest warrants for Israeli Prime Minister Benjamin Netanyahu and Defense Minister Yoav Gallant, as well as Hamas leaders, for alleged war crimes and crimes against humanity.

title: Ireland, Spain, and Norway Recognize Palestine
description: In May 2024, Ireland, Spain, and Norway officially recognized the State of Palestine, joining more than 140 other countries. The move was celebrated by Palestinians and condemned by Israel as 'rewarding terrorism.'

title: ICC Issues Arrest Warrants
description: In July 2024, the International Criminal Court issued arrest warrants for Israeli Prime Minister Benjamin Netanyahu and Defense Minister Yoav Gallant for war crimes and crimes against humanity committed in Gaza, including starvation as a method of warfare.

title: Northern Gaza Offensive
description: In October 2024, Israel launched a major offensive in northern Gaza, particularly targeting Jabalia, with reports of mass evacuations, destruction of entire neighborhoods, and allegations of implementing the 'Generals' Plan' to empty northern Gaza of its population.

title: Continued Siege and Humanitarian Crisis
description: As of 2025, Gaza remains under total siege with severe restrictions on humanitarian aid. Famine conditions affect large portions of the population, the healthcare system has collapsed, and displacement continues. International efforts for a permanent ceasefire have repeatedly failed.
